vapor_pressure¶

Created on Mon Sep 30 23:04:44 2019

@author: yoelr

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Antoine(data, kwargs=None)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Antoine equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
a, b, cfloat

Regressed coefficients.

References

1

Antoine, C. 1888. Tensions des Vapeurs: Nouvelle Relation Entre les Tensions et les Tempé. Compt.Rend. 107:681-684.

2(1,2)

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

3

Yaws, Carl L. The Yaws Handbook of Vapor Pressure: Antoine Coefficients. 1 edition. Houston, Tex: Gulf Publishing Company, 2007.

Examples

Methane, coefficients from [2], at 100 K:

>>> Antoine(100.0, 8.7687, 395.744, -6.469)
34478.367349639906

Tetrafluoromethane, coefficients from [2], at 180 K

>>> Antoine(180, A=8.95894, B=510.595, C=-15.95)
702271.0518579542

Oxygen at 94.91 K, with coefficients from [3] in units of °C, mmHg, log10, showing the conversion of coefficients A (mmHg to Pa) and C (°C to K)

>>> Antoine(94.91, 6.83706+2.1249, 339.2095, 268.70-273.15)
162978.88655572367
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.TRC_Extended_Antoine(data, kwargs=None)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the TRC Extended Antoine equation, as described in [1]. Parameters are chemical dependent, and said to be from the Thermodynamics Research Center (TRC) at Texas A&M. Coefficients for various chemicals can be found in [1].

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K]..

to, a, b, c, n, E, Ffloat

Regressed coefficients.

References

1(1,2,3)

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

Examples

Tetrafluoromethane, coefficients from [1], at 180 K:

>>> TRC_Antoine_extended(180.0, 227.51, -120., 8.95894, 510.595, -15.95, 
... 2.41377, -93.74, 7425.9) 
706317.0898414153
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Wagner_McGraw(data, kwargs=None)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Wagner McGraw equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K]..

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa]..

a, b, c, dfloat

Regressed coefficients.

Notes

Warning: Pc is often treated as adjustable constant.

References

1

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

2

McGarry, Jack. “Correlation and Prediction of the Vapor Pressures of Pure Liquids over Large Pressure Ranges.” Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Process Design and Development 22, no. 2 (April 1, 1983): 313-22. doi:10.1021/i200021a023.

Examples

Methane, coefficients from [2], at 100 K.

>>> Wagner_McGraw(100.0, a=-6.00435, b=1.1885, 
... c=-0.834082, d=-1.22833, Tc=190.53, Pc=4596420.)
34520.44601450496
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Wagner(data, kwargs=None)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Wagner equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K]..

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa]..

a, b, c, dfloat

Regressed coefficients.

Notes

Warning: Pc is often treated as adjustable constant.

References

1

Wagner, W. “New Vapour Pressure Measurements for Argon and Nitrogen and a New Method for Establishing Rational Vapour Pressure Equations.” Cryogenics 13, no. 8 (August 1973): 470-82. doi:10.1016/0011-2275(73)90003-9

2

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

Examples

Methane, coefficients from [2], at 100 K.

>>> Wagner(100., 190.551, 4599200, -6.02242, 1.26652, -0.5707, -1.366)
34415.00476263708
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Boiling_Critical_Relation(data, kwargs=None)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Boiling Critical Relation equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K]..

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa]..

Tbrfloat

Reduced boiling point temperature [Pa]..

hfloat

Regressed coefficients.

Notes

Units are Pa. Formulation makes intuitive sense; a logarithmic form of interpolation.

References

1(1,2)

Reid, Robert C..; Prausnitz, John M.;; Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. McGraw-Hill Companies, 1987.

Examples

Example as in [1] for ethylbenzene

>>> Boiling_Critical_Relation(347.2, 409.3, 617.1, 36E5)
15209.467273093938
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Lee_Kesler(data, kwargs=None)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Lee Kesler equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K]..

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa]..

ωfloat

Acentric factor [-]..

Notes

This equation appears in [1] in expanded form. The reduced pressure form of the equation ensures predicted vapor pressure cannot surpass the critical pressure.

References

1(1,2)

Lee, Byung Ik, and Michael G. Kesler. “A Generalized Thermodynamic Correlation Based on Three-Parameter Corresponding States.” AIChE Journal 21, no. 3 (1975): 510-527. doi:10.1002/aic.690210313.

2

Reid, Robert C..; Prausnitz, John M.;; Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. McGraw-Hill Companies, 1987.

Examples

Example from [2]; ethylbenzene at 347.2 K.

>>> Lee_Kesler(347.2, 617.1, 36E5, 0.299)
13078.694162949312
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Ambrose_Walton(data, kwargs=None)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Ambrose Walton equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K]..

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa]..

ωfloat

Acentric factor [-]..

Notes

Somewhat more accurate than the Lee_Kesler formulation.

References

1

Ambrose, D., and J. Walton. “Vapour Pressures up to Their Critical Temperatures of Normal Alkanes and 1-Alkanols.” Pure and Applied Chemistry 61, no. 8 (1989): 1395-1403. doi:10.1351/pac198961081395.

2

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

Examples

Example from [2]; ethylbenzene at 347.25 K.

>>> Ambrose_Walton(347.25, 617.15, 36.09E5, 0.304)
13278.878504306222
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Sanjari(data, kwargs=None)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Sanjari equation, as described in [Rbd411eb5dcee-1].

rac{a_{10}}{T_r} + a_{11}ln T_r + a_{12} T_r^{1.9}

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K]..

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa]..

ωfloat

Acentric factor [-]..

Notes

Although developed for refrigerants, this model should have some general predictive ability.

a[1-12] are as follows: 6.83377, -5.76051, 0.90654, -1.16906, 5.32034, -28.1460, -58.0352, 23.57466, 18.19967, 16.33839, 65.6995, -35.9739.

For a claimed fluid not included in the regression, R128, the claimed AARD was 0.428%. A re-calculation using 200 data points from 125.45 K to 343.90225 K evenly spaced by 1.09775 K as generated by NIST Webbook April 2016 produced an AARD of 0.644%. It is likely that the author’s regression used more precision in its coefficients than was shown here. Nevertheless, the function is reproduced as shown in [Rbd411eb5dcee-1].

For Tc=808 K, Pc=1100000 Pa, omega=1.1571, this function actually declines after 770 K.

Examples

>>> Sanjari(347.2, 617.1, 36E5, 0.299)
13651.916109552498
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Edalat(data, kwargs=None)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Edalat equation, as described in [1].

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K]..

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa]..

ωfloat

Acentric factor [-]..

Notes

Claimed to have a higher accuracy than the Lee-Kesler CSP relationship. [1] found an average error of 6.06% on 94 compounds and 1106 data points.

References

1(1,2)

Edalat, M., R. B. Bozar-Jomehri, and G. A. Mansoori. “Generalized Equation Predicts Vapor Pressure of Hydrocarbons.” Oil and Gas Journal; 91:5 (February 1, 1993).

Examples

>>> Edalat(347.2, 617.1, 36E5, 0.299)
13461.273080743307
